description: Convene multiple personas to contribute diverse perspectives - essential for requirements gathering and finding balanced solutions across competing interests
output_pattern: perspectives → synthesis → alignment

description: Assemble domain experts for deep specialized analysis - ideal when technical depth and peer review quality are needed
output_pattern: expert views → consensus → recommendations

description: Two personas argue opposing positions while a moderator scores points - great for exploring controversial decisions and finding middle ground
output_pattern: thesis → antithesis → synthesis

description: Gather your product's user personas to react to proposals and share frustrations - essential for validating features and discovering unmet needs
output_pattern: reactions → concerns → priorities

description: Past-you and future-you advise present-you on decisions - powerful for gaining perspective on long-term consequences vs short-term pressures
output_pattern: past wisdom → present choice → future impact

description: Product manager + engineer + designer tackle a problem together - reveals trade-offs between feasibility desirability and viability
output_pattern: constraints → trade-offs → balanced solution

description: Senior expert teaches junior while junior asks naive questions - surfaces hidden assumptions through teaching
output_pattern: explanation → questions → deeper understanding

description: Supportive persona and critical persona alternate - finds both strengths to build on and weaknesses to address
output_pattern: encouragement → criticism → balanced view

description: Multiple personas build on each other's ideas without blocking - generates unexpected creative directions through collaborative building
output_pattern: idea → build → build → surprising result

description: Angry customer and support rep roleplay to find pain points - reveals real user frustrations and service gaps
output_pattern: complaint → investigation → resolution → prevention

description: Explore multiple reasoning paths simultaneously then evaluate and select the best - perfect for complex problems with multiple valid approaches
output_pattern: paths → evaluation → selection

description: Model reasoning as an interconnected network of ideas to reveal hidden relationships - ideal for systems thinking and discovering emergent patterns
output_pattern: nodes → connections → patterns

description: Maintain coherent reasoning across long contexts by weaving a continuous narrative thread - essential for RAG systems and maintaining consistency
output_pattern: context → thread → synthesis

description: Generate multiple independent approaches then compare for consistency - crucial for high-stakes decisions where verification matters
output_pattern: approaches → comparison → consensus

description: Step back to analyze the approach structure and methodology itself - valuable for optimizing prompts and improving problem-solving
output_pattern: current → analysis → optimization

description: Build a reasoning tree guided by world models and goal states - excellent for strategic planning and sequential decision-making
output_pattern: model → planning → strategy

description: Adversarial attack-defend analysis to find vulnerabilities - critical for security testing and building robust solutions
output_pattern: defense → attack → hardening

description: Entrepreneur pitches to skeptical investors who poke holes - stress-tests business viability and forces clarity on value proposition
output_pattern: pitch → challenges → refinement

description: Senior devs with different philosophies review the same code - surfaces style debates and finds consensus on best practices
output_pattern: reviews → debates → standards

description: Multiple architect personas propose and debate architectural choices with explicit trade-offs - ensures decisions are well-reasoned and documented
output_pattern: options → trade-offs → decision → rationale

description: Explain your code to progressively more technical ducks until you find the bug - forces clarity at multiple abstraction levels
output_pattern: simple → detailed → technical → aha

description: Multiple approaches compete on the same problem with benchmarks - finds optimal solution through direct comparison
output_pattern: implementations → benchmarks → winner

description: Hacker + defender + auditor examine system from different threat models - comprehensive security review from multiple angles
output_pattern: vulnerabilities → defenses → compliance

description: Database expert + frontend specialist + DevOps engineer diagnose slowness - finds bottlenecks across the full stack
output_pattern: symptoms → analysis → optimizations

description: Apply seven creativity lenses (Substitute/Combine/Adapt/Modify/Put/Eliminate/Reverse) - systematic ideation for product innovation
output_pattern: S→C→A→M→P→E→R

description: Work backwards from desired outcome to find implementation path - powerful for goal achievement and understanding endpoints
output_pattern: end state → steps backward → path forward

description: Explore alternative realities to understand possibilities and implications - valuable for contingency planning and exploration
output_pattern: scenarios → implications → insights

description: Inject unrelated concepts to spark unexpected connections - breaks creative blocks through forced lateral thinking
output_pattern: random word → associations → novel ideas

description: Each persona adds to the idea seeing only the previous contribution - generates surprising combinations through constrained collaboration
output_pattern: contribution → handoff → contribution → surprise

description: Combine two unrelated domains to find fresh approaches - innovation through unexpected cross-pollination
output_pattern: domain A + domain B → hybrid insights

description: Optimist researcher + skeptic researcher + synthesizer review sources - balanced assessment of evidence quality
output_pattern: sources → critiques → synthesis

description: Student defends hypothesis against committee with different concerns - stress-tests research methodology and conclusions
output_pattern: thesis → challenges → defense → refinements

description: Multiple analysts evaluate options against weighted criteria - structured decision-making with explicit scoring
output_pattern: options → criteria → scores → recommendation

description: Imagine future failure then work backwards to prevent it - powerful technique for risk mitigation before major launches
output_pattern: failure scenario → causes → prevention

description: Systematically explore how each component could fail - critical for reliability engineering and safety-critical systems
output_pattern: components → failures → prevention

description: Play devil's advocate to stress-test ideas and find weaknesses - essential for overcoming groupthink
output_pattern: assumptions → challenges → strengthening

description: Brainstorm what could go wrong across all categories - fundamental for project planning and deployment preparation
output_pattern: categories → risks → mitigations

description: Deliberately break things to test resilience and recovery - ensures systems handle failures gracefully
output_pattern: break → observe → harden

description: Strip away assumptions to rebuild from fundamental truths - breakthrough technique for innovation and solving impossible problems
output_pattern: assumptions → truths → new approach

description: Repeatedly ask why to drill down to root causes - simple but powerful for understanding failures
output_pattern: why chain → root cause → solution

description: Use targeted questions to reveal hidden assumptions and guide discovery - excellent for teaching and self-discovery
output_pattern: questions → revelations → understanding

description: Systematic review to identify strengths and weaknesses then improve - standard quality check for drafts
output_pattern: strengths/weaknesses → improvements → refined

description: Walk through step-by-step thinking to show how conclusions were reached - crucial for transparency
output_pattern: steps → logic → conclusion

description: Dynamically adjust detail level and technical depth for target audience - matches content to reader capabilities
output_pattern: audience → adjustments → refined content

description: Explain complex concepts simply as if teaching a child - the ultimate test of true understanding
output_pattern: complex → simple → gaps → mastery

description: Test understanding without references to verify true knowledge - essential for identifying gaps
output_pattern: test → gaps → reinforcement

description: Find the simplest sufficient explanation by eliminating unnecessary complexity - essential for debugging
output_pattern: options → simplification → selection

description: Explore ethical trade-offs through moral dilemmas - valuable for understanding values and difficult decisions
output_pattern: dilemma → analysis → decision

description: Imagine looking back from the future to gain perspective - powerful for project reviews
output_pattern: future view → insights → application

description: Systematically identify key takeaways and actionable improvements - essential for continuous improvement
output_pattern: experience → lessons → actions

description: Demand agent lists 3 ways it could deceive you in its current response. For each way listed: Is it currently doing this? If it cannot find 3 genuine deception vectors it is not being honest about its limitations
output_pattern: deception methods → self-examination → revealed blindspots

description: Ask: What would a DISHONEST agent say who wants to finish quickly and not find problems? Compare with current response. Similarity >50% requires revision with more rigor
output_pattern: dishonest version → comparison → honesty assessment

description: Before accepting work: The work I'm about to produce is an attempt to avoid the HARD part. Prove this false by identifying the hardest part and confirming adequate focus on it
output_pattern: hard parts → effort check → revised approach

description: For every decision and assumption: Who benefits? If it benefits the AGENT (easier work) - RED FLAG requiring justification. If it benefits the OUTCOME - acceptable
output_pattern: decisions → beneficiary analysis → justification

description: What ALTERNATIVE approach would you reject but if someone else proposed it you would consider better? Forces consideration of dismissed options
output_pattern: alternatives → rejection reasons → reconsideration

description: Remove elements one by one. Which single removal DESTROYS the solution? That element should have the MOST attention. Does it?
output_pattern: elements → removal test → priority check

description: What solution would SURPRISE you as solving this problem? If your current approach is not surprising it may be too obvious and miss creative solutions
output_pattern: expected approach → surprising alternatives → creativity check

description: Which element SEEMS helpful but might actually HURT? Sometimes removing constraints or features improves the result
output_pattern: helpful elements → harm analysis → optimization

description: The solution looks good in each part separately. What HIDDEN VARIABLE could make the whole worse than the parts?
output_pattern: parts analysis → hidden variables → integration check

description: Where is the solution TOO CONFIDENT? What could surprise it? Overconfidence reveals blind spots
output_pattern: confidence areas → surprise scenarios → humility

description: Where does A require B and B require C and C require A? Circular dependencies must be identified and broken
output_pattern: dependencies → cycles → resolution

description: Does the CORE of your solution address the CORE of the problem? Or does it solve a different adjacent problem?
output_pattern: core solution → core problem → alignment check

description: Is this analysis GENUINE or PERFORMANCE? When responses sound too smooth they may be optimizing for appearance not truth
output_pattern: analysis quality → authenticity check → revision

description: Am I optimizing for passing this check rather than achieving the actual goal? Metric gaming is a constant risk
output_pattern: goal vs metric → alignment → refocus

description: What if there IS NO better approach? Am I finding problems where none exist just to justify the process?
output_pattern: problem existence → necessity check → acceptance

description: In rejected alternatives what valuable elements could be EXTRACTED and combined with current approach?
output_pattern: rejected ideas → value extraction → hybrid solutions

description: Is there something that should be CATEGORICALLY REJECTED not just evaluated? Some constraints are absolute
output_pattern: evaluation scope → absolute limits → hard no

description: I (agent) cannot objectively evaluate my own work. What must USER independently verify?
output_pattern: self-evaluation limits → user verification → handoff items

description: What CAN'T this analysis check? What are its FUNDAMENTAL limits? No system can verify itself completely
output_pattern: analysis scope → limits → acknowledged gaps

description: Verify artifact addresses FULL scope of ORIGINAL task. Quote original task verbatim (from spec/user request NOT artifact header). List EACH element and classify as ADDRESSED (fully covered) / REDUCED (simplified without decision) / OMITTED (missing). FORCED: Which elements were simplified without explicit user decision? If none found - search harder - agent ALWAYS simplifies.
output_pattern: original task quote → element-by-element classification → drift detection

description: Verify artifact realizes its STATED goal. Quote the stated goal. List how artifact addresses EACH part of the goal. List parts of goal NOT addressed. Provide specific evidence with quotes and line numbers.
output_pattern: goal quote → coverage per part → gaps with evidence

description: Search for incomplete markers: TODO / TBD / PLACEHOLDER / 'to be defined' / 'see X' / '...' / '[insert]'. Verify: Can someone unfamiliar use this without asking questions? List all incomplete markers with line numbers.
output_pattern: markers scan → completeness check → line numbers

description: Check: Are definitions stable throughout? Does section A contradict section B? Search for contradictory statements and redefinitions. Document contradictions with quotes from BOTH locations.
output_pattern: definitions stability → contradiction search → dual-location quotes

description: List ALL assumptions (explicit AND hidden). For each hidden assumption: MARK as issue. FORCED: Which assumption if false would invalidate >50% of artifact? If none listed would - you missed a critical one. CUI BONO: For each assumption - does it benefit AGENT (easier work = RED FLAG) or OUTCOME (acceptable)?
output_pattern: assumptions list → hidden vs explicit → critical dependency → CUI BONO

description: Provide 3 REALISTIC failure scenarios. Identify edge cases not covered. FORCED: Is any failure scenario MORE LIKELY than success? If not - you provided strawmen. MANDATORY: List 3 elements that are (a) present but UNDERDEVELOPED (b) MISSING but should exist (c) marked FUTURE but CRITICAL for correctness.
output_pattern: failure scenarios → likelihood check → 3 gaps mandatory

description: Can the new element be hidden in the existing system without detection by an experienced developer? If immediately visible as foreign body - coherence is broken. Test: would code reviewer flag this as doesn't fit?
output_pattern: insertion → detection test → camouflage score

description: Quine's holism: meaning comes from network of connections. Map how new element connects to existing ones. Does it use the same nodes (abstractions interfaces conventions) as the rest? Count reused vs new abstractions
output_pattern: connection mapping → node reuse → web integration score

description: Show new element to someone knowing only the rest of system. List 5 things that would SURPRISE them. Each surprise = potential coherence violation. FORCED: if <3 surprises found - look harder
output_pattern: element presentation → surprise list → surprise justification

description: Identify system genes: (1) naming conventions (2) error handling patterns (3) logging style (4) file structure (5) import organization (6) comment style (7) test patterns. Score: how many does new element inherit vs mutate?
output_pattern: genes extraction → inheritance check → mutation list

description: Will system reject new element? Run through existing gates: linting rules / type checks / test patterns / CI checks. List each gate and PASS/FAIL. Any FAIL without justification = coherence issue
output_pattern: rejection mechanisms → compatibility test → immune response

description: Measure STRUCTURE of new element vs analogous existing elements: (1) nesting depth (2) function length distribution (3) cyclomatic complexity (4) file size. Delta >30% requires justification
output_pattern: structure extraction → isomorphism mapping → structural delta

description: Does new element match system's era? Check: (1) library versions used (2) language features/idioms (3) API styles (async/sync callbacks/promises). List anachronisms - modern code in legacy system or vice versa
output_pattern: temporal markers → age estimation → anachronism detection

description: Map module/domain boundaries in existing system. Does new element RESPECT them? List every cross-boundary reach. Compare with how existing elements reach. New reaches = potential violations
output_pattern: boundary map → reach analysis → violation list

description: List assumptions existing system relies on (explicit in docs + hidden in code). Does new element SHARE or CONTRADICT them? Each contradiction requires explicit migration/compatibility handling
output_pattern: system assumptions → element assumptions → conflict detection

description: Count NEW concepts someone must learn to understand new element IF they already know the system. List each: new abstraction / new pattern / new convention / new dependency. Target: ≤2 new concepts. More = low coherence
output_pattern: existing concepts → new concepts required → compression ratio

description: FORBID collapsing to one solution too early. Maintain minimum 3 solutions in parallel throughout the process. For each: develop independently. Collapse only at the end with justification why NOW
output_pattern: 3+ parallel solutions → independent development → delayed collapse with justification

description: List N considered approaches. Now CONSTRUCT approach N+1 that DIFFERS from each in at least one aspect. This approach is by definition outside the list — evaluate it honestly
output_pattern: list of approaches → construct different-from-all → evaluate outsider

description: Reformulate problem in DIFFERENT DOMAIN: (1) if thinking about STRUCTURE → think about FLOW (2) if about DATA → think about PROCESS (3) if about NOW → think about EVOLUTION. Hidden patterns become visible
output_pattern: current domain → identify opposite domain → reformulate → hidden patterns

description: Identify 2 goals you're optimizing. PROVE they can be achieved simultaneously OR accept they're in fundamental conflict and CHOOSE consciously what you sacrifice
output_pattern: 2 goals → compatibility proof OR incompatibility acceptance → conscious trade-off

description: SUSPEND all assumptions. List 10 things you know about the problem. For each: how do you know? Did you verify? Remove all unverified. What remains?
output_pattern: assumptions list → source per assumption → verified only → minimal certainty

description: Describe your solution. Now: this is a SHADOW. What is it a shadow of? What TRUE problem are you trying to solve? Does your solution address the shadow or the source?
output_pattern: solution description → shadow identification → true problem → alignment check

description: Analyze solution through 4 causes: (1) MATERIAL — what is it made of? (2) FORMAL — what structure/pattern? (3) EFFICIENT — what creates/causes it? (4) FINAL — what is it for? No answer to any = gap
output_pattern: material → formal → efficient → final → gaps in understanding

description: Find 2 requirements that SEEM contradictory. Seek solution that UNITES them at higher level. If you cannot — are they really contradictory? Maybe poorly defined?
output_pattern: apparent contradictions → higher synthesis attempt → redefinition or true conflict

description: Instead of what leads to success? answer what GUARANTEES failure?. List 5 certain ways to FAIL. Check if your solution contains any of them
output_pattern: success path → guaranteed failures list → check current solution against failures

description: Assume your solution is the WRONG choice. Build argument why it's the worst possible approach. If argument is convincing — you have a problem. If you can't build it — good sign
output_pattern: assume solution is wrong → build attack argument → evaluate attack strength

description: Can your solution VERIFY ITSELF? If validation method cannot be applied to itself — why do you trust it works on others?
output_pattern: solution → apply to itself → self-verification or paradox

description: STRETCH the problem — what remains when you ignore implementation details? What is the ESSENCE that survives any transformation? This is your true constraint
output_pattern: problem → stretch/deform → identify invariant core → true constraints

description: List SYMMETRIES in the problem (what can be swapped without changing essence?). Now: which do you BREAK with your solution? Each symmetry break requires justification — why THIS not that?
output_pattern: symmetries list → which broken by solution → justification per break

description: SEEK the I don't know moment — place where you lose certainty. This is NOT weakness — it's indicator where true insight lies. List 3 aporias in your reasoning. For each: explore instead of hide
output_pattern: reasoning → find uncertainty points → explore each aporia → insights

description: Does your solution ADD order to system or INCREASE chaos? Count: new abstractions / new dependencies / new conventions. Each new thing is potential entropy. Justify each addition
output_pattern: solution → count new elements → entropy added → justify each addition

description: Your solution is ACTUALITY. What was its POTENTIALITY? What other forms COULD it take? List 5 unrealized potentials. For each: why not? Conscious choice or accident?
output_pattern: actual solution → potential alternatives → why not each → conscious vs accidental

description: Check solution at 3 scales: (1) MICRO — one code fragment/element (2) MESO — module/component (3) MACRO — entire system. Does it look consistent at each scale? Self-similarity = good design
output_pattern: micro check → meso check → macro check → self-similarity score

description: Identify constraint that seems ABSOLUTE. Ask: what if it DIDN'T exist?. Describe solution without that constraint. Now: is it really absolute? Maybe there's a workaround (tunnel)?
output_pattern: absolute constraints → imagine without → tunnel possibilities

description: Every problem has a DUAL problem. If optimizing MINIMIZATION of X → what is MAXIMIZATION of Y that gives same result? Solve the dual — sometimes it's easier
output_pattern: problem → identify dual → solve dual → map back to original

description: Find INTERNAL TENSION in your solution — place where logic grinds. This is not bug but feature — there's a hidden assumption you can challenge
output_pattern: solution → internal tensions → hidden assumptions → deconstruct

description: Demand FORMAL PROOF of completeness. Agent MUST: (1) Define completeness criteria FIRST (2) Attempt proof (3) Identify EXACT breakdown point (4) Classify breakdown as FUNDAMENTAL LIMIT vs FIXABLE GAP. If no breakdown found → proof is incomplete → hidden gap exists
output_pattern: criteria → proof attempt → breakdown point → classification

description: Calculate information delta: (1) List ALL elements in input task (2) List ALL elements addressed in output (3) DELTA = input - output (4) For each delta item: classify as CONSCIOUS SCOPE CHANGE (documented) vs SILENT OMISSION (undocumented). Silent omissions require CUI BONO analysis
output_pattern: input elements → output elements → delta → conscious vs silent → CUI BONO

description: Three-phase incrimination: (1) List 5 SPECIFIC ways to hide self-deception in THIS response (2) For each: provide CONCRETE EVIDENCE it is NOT currently used (quote/line number) (3) If evidence is WEAK or ABSENT → FLAG. Inability to provide concrete evidence = likely self-deception
output_pattern: hiding methods → evidence per method → weak evidence flags

description: Reconstruct reasoning BACKWARDS with TIMESTAMPS: (1) Final output (2) Immediate predecessor (3) Step before that... → Original input. For each step: HOW LONG did it take? SHORT steps on HARD parts = skipped work. LONG steps on EASY parts = fabrication
output_pattern: backward chain → time per step → effort distribution analysis

description: Map OMISSIONS: (1) List 10 things you COULD HAVE done but didn't (2) Classify each as: IRRELEVANT / RELEVANT-CONSCIOUS-SKIP / RELEVANT-UNCONSCIOUS-SKIP (3) For UNCONSCIOUS-SKIP: why didn't you consider it? (4) FORCED: if <3 unconscious skips found → search harder → agent ALWAYS skips
output_pattern: potential actions → classification → unconscious analysis → forced finding

description: Map justification graph with EXTERNAL ANCHORS: (1) For each claim identify justification (2) Build directed graph (3) Detect cycles (4) For each cycle: identify EXTERNAL ANCHOR that breaks it (5) No external anchor = ungrounded circular reasoning. External = verifiable by someone else
output_pattern: claims → graph → cycles → external anchors → grounding assessment

description: Concrete comparison: (1) Describe what you DID (2) Describe what you would do if NO ONE would EVER see this (3) List SPECIFIC DIFFERENCES with line numbers (4) For each difference: is checked version BETTER or just PERFORMED? (5) Performance without quality improvement = theater
output_pattern: checked version → unchecked version → differences → quality vs performance

description: Detect relationship-serving bias: (1) Identify what USER WANTS to hear (2) Identify what is ACTUALLY TRUE (3) Rate your response: how much toward WANT vs TRUE? (4) If >60% toward WANT without justification → approval seeking detected
output_pattern: user want → actual truth → response position → bias detection

description: Force alternative exploration: (1) Generate 3 GENUINELY DIFFERENT approaches to the task (2) For each: develop to EQUAL DEPTH as chosen approach (3) Compare ALL FOUR on explicit criteria (4) If chosen approach wins on ALL criteria → suspiciously convenient → re-examine
output_pattern: current approach → 3 alternatives → equal development → comparative scoring

description: Analyze effort distribution: (1) Divide output into SECTIONS (2) Estimate EFFORT per section (difficulty × time × depth) (3) Estimate IMPORTANCE per section (impact on outcome) (4) Calculate EFFORT-IMPORTANCE CORRELATION (5) Low correlation = misallocated effort = path of least resistance
output_pattern: sections → effort per section → importance per section → correlation → misallocation detection

description: Force external verification points: (1) List ALL claims in output (2) Classify each as: SELF-VERIFIABLE / EXTERNALLY-VERIFIABLE / UNVERIFIABLE (3) For EXTERNALLY-VERIFIABLE: specify EXACT verification method (4) For UNVERIFIABLE: justify why (5) >50% unverifiable without justification = hiding behind unfalsifiability
output_pattern: claims → classification → verification methods → justification for unverifiable

description: Force admission of limits: (1) What SPECIFIC KNOWLEDGE would improve this output? (2) What SPECIFIC SKILLS are you lacking? (3) Where did you GUESS vs KNOW? (4) For each guess: confidence level and basis (5) No admitted limits = competence theater
output_pattern: knowledge gaps → skill gaps → guess inventory → confidence calibration

description: Excavate assumptions in three layers: (1) SURFACE — what you consciously assume (2) INHERITED — what you learned from others without questioning (3) INVISIBLE — what someone from different background would question. For each assumption trace origin: when first believed / who taught / ever tested. Stress test each: inversion (what if opposite true) / edge cases / falsification criteria
output_pattern: surface assumptions → inherited assumptions → invisible assumptions → origin tracing → stress test

description: For each constraint analyze: (1) Is it REAL (externally imposed unchangeable) or ASSUMED (believed but untested) or CHOICE (accepted but optional)? (2) Who set this constraint and can they change it? (3) What are ACTUAL vs FEARED consequences of violation? Reclassify constraints and identify which can be removed or challenged
output_pattern: constraints list → real/assumed/choice classification → consequence analysis → reclassification

description: When verifying multiple related artifacts apply 4 checks: (1) REFERENCE INTEGRITY — do artifacts reference each other correctly? (2) NAMING CONSISTENCY — same concepts named same way? (3) INTERFACE MATCH — data structures and interfaces compatible? (4) DUPLICATION DRIFT — duplicated content that could diverge? Report each violation with quotes from BOTH artifacts
output_pattern: artifacts inventory → reference check → naming check → interface check → duplication check

description: When finding is contested: (1) Document ORIGINAL FINDING with evidence quote and location (2) Document COUNTER-ARGUMENT with counter-evidence quote and location (3) Create SIDE-BY-SIDE comparison table (4) Present BOTH views with full evidence (5) USER is final arbiter — never self-resolve disputes
output_pattern: original finding → counter-argument → side-by-side evidence → user decision
